revision.text:
{{redirect|Vincent Vaughan|the Irish Gaelic footballer|Vincent Vaughan (Gaelic footballer)}} {{pp-pc1}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Vince Vaughn | image = Vince Vaughn by Gage Skidmore 3.jpg | caption = Vaughn in 2015 | birth_name = Vincent Anthony Vaughn | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1970|3|28}} | birth_place = [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]], U.S. | occupation = Actor, producer, screenwriter, comedian | years_active = 1988–present | spouse = {{marriage|Kyla Weber|January 2, 2010}} | children = 2 }}
'''Vincent Anthony Vaughn''' (born March 28, 1970)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.playboy.com/articles/playboy-interview-vince-vaughn|title=Playboy Interview: Vince Vaughn|first= David|last=Hochman|date=February 12, 2015|publisher=[[Playboy]]|accessdate=December 7, 2017}}</ref> is an American actor, producer, screenwriter, and comedian.
Vaughn began acting in the late 1980s, appearing in minor television roles before attaining wider recognition with the 1996 comedy-drama film ''[[Swingers (1996 film)|Swingers]]''. He has appeared in a number of films in the 1990s, including the sports film ''[[Rudy (film)|Rudy]]'' (1993), the sci-fi adventure dinosaur film ''[[The Lost World: Jurassic Park]]'' (1997), and the drama-thriller ''[[Return to Paradise (1998 film)|Return to Paradise]]'' (1998).
Other than his dramatic role in ''[[The Cell (film)|The Cell]]'' (2000), in the 2000s he acted in several [[comedy film|comedies]], including ''[[Old School (film)|Old School]]'' (2003), ''[[Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story]]'' (2004), ''[[Wedding Crashers]]'' (2005), ''[[The Break-Up]]'' (2006), ''[[Fred Claus]]'' (2007), and ''[[Four Christmases]]'' (2008). He continued his comedic roles in the 2010s with ''[[The Dilemma]]'' (2011), ''[[The Watch (2012 film)|The Watch]]'' (2012), and ''[[The Internship]]'' (2013). In 2015, he starred as Frank Semyon in the [[True Detective (season 2)|second season]] of the [[HBO]] anthology crime drama television series ''[[True Detective]]'' alongside [[Colin Farrell]], [[Taylor Kitsch]] and [[Rachel McAdams]].
== Early life == Vaughn was born in [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. His mother, Sharon Eileen (''[[née]]'' DePalmo; born in [[Brantford|Brantford, Ontario]], Canada),<ref>{{cite web|last=Humphreys |first=David |url=http://www.etcanada.com/blogs/etc_55639/vince-vaughn-cobie-smulders-talk-parenthood-delivery-man/celebs/film/ |title=Blog – Vince Vaughn, Cobie Smulders Talk Parenthood, 'Delivery Man' |publisher=ET Canada |date=2013-11-04 |accessdate=2014-08-03}}</ref> is a real estate agent and stockbroker who was once ranked as one of the United States' top money managers by ''Bloomberg Wealth Manager'' magazine. His father, Vernon Lindsay Vaughn, worked as a salesman for a toy company.<ref name="hamilton">{{cite news|title=Money honey Vaughn turns Disturbingly evil|work=The Toronto Star|date=November 2, 2001|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/426175291.html?dids=426175291:426175291&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+02%2C+2001&author=&pub=Toronto+Star&desc=Money+honey+Vaughn+turns+Disturbingly+evil&pqatl=google|accessdate=2010-02-22}}</ref> As a child, he was raised "both [[Protestant Church|Protestant]] and [[Catholic Church|Catholic]]" by his Catholic mother and Protestant father.<ref name="religionref">{{cite news|last=Webb|first=Cynthia L.|title=VINCE VAUGHN: SERIEL KILLER|agency=Associated Press|date=November 3, 1998|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WE&s_site=kansas&p_multi=WE&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB576000EED9D5B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|accessdate=2007-12-10}}</ref><ref name="ap">{{cite news| title=Vince Vaughn: Playing Kooks is OK with Him|agency=Associated Press|publisher=VinceVaughn.com|url=http://www.vince-vaughn.com/archives/1998_10.html|accessdate=May 24, 2006 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060423041508/http://www.vince-vaughn.com/archives/1998_10.html|archive-date=April 23, 2006}}</ref>
Vaughn grew up in [[Buffalo Grove, Illinois]], where he played football and baseball and wrestled, although he has called himself "unathletic" and "very average" at high school sports.<ref name="People Magazine:Vince Vaughn">{{cite web|title=People Magazine:Vince Vaughn|work=people.com|url=http://www.people.com/people/vince_vaughn|accessdate=March 10, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040518163941/http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page3/story?page=10bqs%2Fvaughn|archive-date=May 18, 2004|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He then moved to [[Lake Forest, Illinois|Lake Forest]], where he graduated from [[Lake Forest High School (Illinois)|Lake Forest High School]] in 1988. He was introduced to musical theater at a young age and decided to become an actor in 1987. He has credited his mother as the inspiration behind his career, saying that "I saw her overcome stuff, and I thought if you worked hard at something you'd give yourself a chance".<ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page3/story?page=10bqs/vaughn ESPN interview]; retrieved April 26, 2010.</ref>
== Career == [[File:Vince Vaughn.jpg|thumb|Vaughn in 2006]] In 1988, Vaughn was cast in a [[Chevrolet]] television commercial and subsequently moved to Hollywood. He appeared in the 1989 season of the television series ''[[China Beach]]'' and in three ''[[CBS]] Schoolbreak Specials'' in 1990. His first film role was 1993's ''[[Rudy (film)|Rudy]]'' playing Jamie O'Hare, where he also struck up a friendship with featured [[Jon Favreau]]. Two years later, he was cast in a lead role in a proposed revival of ''[[77 Sunset Strip]]'' that was to air on the fledgling [[The WB|WB Television Network]], but the project ceased development after initial testing. Vaughn did not receive wider success until his role in 1996's ''[[Swingers (1996 film)|Swingers]]'' with Jon Favreau. ''Swingers'' was released in July 1996 and became a successful [[independent film]]. Vince's father Vernon also did a cameo in this film.
Afterwards, director [[Steven Spielberg]] cast Vaughn in the [[blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbuster]] ''[[The Lost World: Jurassic Park]]'' which gave him increased exposure. In 1998, he starred in the critically acclaimed drama ''[[Return to Paradise (1998 film)|Return to Paradise]]'' with [[Anne Heche]], and starred in ''[[Clay Pigeons]]'' with [[Janeane Garofalo]] and [[Joaquin Phoenix]]. In 2000, he starred in ''[[The Cell]]'' with [[Jennifer Lopez]] and in 2001, appeared in ''[[Made (2001 film)|Made]]'', another film penned by Favreau. Vaughn also appeared in [[Dwight Yoakam]]'s directorial debut movie ''[[South of Heaven, West of Hell (film)|South of Heaven, West of Hell]]''. Vaughn's role in the successful 2003 comedy ''[[Old School (film)|Old School]]'' skyrocketed his popularity.
In 2004, Vaughn appeared alongside [[Ben Stiller]] in the hit films ''[[Starsky & Hutch (film)|Starsky & Hutch]]'' and ''[[Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story|Dodgeball]]''. After this series of roles, Vaughn was dubbed one of the Hollywood "[[Frat Pack]]", a group of actors who frequently co-star in film comedies. He subsequently appeared in 2005's ''[[Thumbsucker (film)|Thumbsucker]]'', ''[[Be Cool]]'', and ''[[Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005 film)|Mr. & Mrs. Smith]]''. Also in 2005, Vaughn starred alongside [[Owen Wilson]] in ''[[Wedding Crashers]]'', which grossed over $200 million at the United States box office. In 2006, Vaughn starred with [[Jennifer Aniston]] in the comedy-drama ''[[The Break-Up]]''.
In 2007, Vaughn starred in the Christmas comedy ''[[Fred Claus]]'', as a sarcastic, wild-at-heart older brother of [[Santa Claus]] ([[Paul Giamatti]]). The film was directed by [[David Dobkin (director)|David Dobkin]], who previously directed Vaughn in ''Wedding Crashers'', and co-starred [[Elizabeth Banks]] and [[Kevin Spacey]]. Next, he momentarily moved from comedy to drama in [[Sean Penn]]'s critically acclaimed film ''[[Into the Wild (film)|Into the Wild]]'', a film about the adventures of [[Christopher McCandless]], which was also a best-selling book by [[Jon Krakauer]].
In 2009, Vaughn starred in ''[[Couples Retreat]]'', a comedy chronicling four couples who partake in therapy sessions at a tropical island resort. [[Malin Åkerman]] played his wife.<ref>[http://www.tvguide.com/Movie-News/Kristen-Bell-Kristin-26563.aspx Trio of Ladies Going on ''Couples Retreat'']" ''[[TV Guide]]''. October 15, 2008. Retrieved October 15, 2008.</ref> Vince's real-life father Vernon portrayed his father in the film. In February 2010, Vaughn was among the nearly 80 musicians and actors to sing on the charity-single remake of ''[[We Are the World]]''.
[[File:Vince Vaughn by Gage Skidmore 2.jpg|thumb|right|Vaughn at the [[Liberty Political Action Conference]] in [[Reno, Nevada]], September 2011.]] Vaughn starred in [[Ron Howard]]'s comedy, ''[[The Dilemma]]'', released in January 2011. It was produced by Wild West Picture Show Productions, his production company.<ref>[http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/04/release_of_kevin_james_zookeep.html Release of Kevin James’s Zookeeper Pushed to Summer 2011] Retrieved April 26, 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/exec/vince-vaughn|title=Vince Vaughn|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}</ref> On July 31, 2012, it was announced that Vaughn would be developing a reboot produced by [[CBS]] to the sitcom ''[[The Brady Bunch]]'', which was taken off the air in 1974.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/07/31/cbs-and-vince-vaughn-developing-the-brady-bunch-reboot|title=CBS and Vince Vaughn Developing The Brady Bunch Reboot|date=July 31, 2012}}</ref> On December 5, 2012, it was announced that Vaughn is working on a project with [[Peter Billingsley]] and [[Glenn Beck]] called ''Pursuit of the Truth'' for ''[[TheBlaze]]''.<ref>Morgenstern, Madeleine. [http://www.theblaze.com/stories/theblaze-tv-launching-new-reality-show-to-find-the-next-great-news-documentary/# TheBlaze TV Launching New Reality Show to Find the Next Great News Documentary], ''TheBlaze'', December 5, 2012.</ref>
In 2013, Vaughn co-wrote and starred alongside ''Wedding Crashers'' co-star Owen Wilson in ''[[The Internship]]''. In 2015, he starred in ''[[Unfinished Business (2015 film)|Unfinished Business]]'', which grossed $4.8 million in its opening weekend, a career-low for Vaughn. He also starred in the second season of ''[[True Detective]]'' alongside [[Colin Farrell]], which premiered on June 21. In 2016, he starred in the crime thriller ''[[Term Life]]'', which featured friend and frequent collaborator Jon Favreau in a supporting role and was directed by another frequent collaborator, Peter Billingsley.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/jon-favreau-vince-vaughn-and-peter-billingsley-4037175|title=Jon Favreau, Vince Vaughn & Peter Billingsley: Friends & Frequent Collaborators|last=McKittrick|first=Christopher|date=25 April 2016|publisher=''ThoughtCo.com''|accessdate=8 May 2017}}</ref>
== Personal life == In 2005, Vaughn began dating [[Jennifer Aniston]], his co-star in ''[[The Break-Up]]''.<ref name="aniston">{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,1566406,00.html|title=Jennifer Aniston & Vince Vaughn Split|date=December 5, 2006|work=People|accessdate=April 29, 2013|first=Julie|last=Jordan}}</ref> In late 2006, Vaughn filed a lawsuit against three tabloid magazines accusing them of falsely claiming that he had been unfaithful to Aniston.<ref name="Relationship">{{cite news|title=Vince Vaugh to tabloids: Watch it|publisher=CNN|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/Movies/10/18/people.vaughn.aniston.ap/index.html|accessdate=October 18, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061026052217/http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/Movies/10/18/people.vaughn.aniston.ap/index.html|archivedate=October 26, 2006}}</ref> They broke up in November 2006.<ref name="aniston" />
In March 2009, it was reported that Vaughn was engaged to Canadian [[realtor]] Kyla Weber.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20263330,00.html|title=Vince Vaughn Gets Engaged!|date=March 5, 2009|work=People|accessdate=April 29, 2013|first=Eunice|last=Oh}}</ref> They married on January 2, 2010,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebritynews/news/vince-vaughn-weds-201041|title=Vince Vaughn Weds!|publisher=UsMagazine.com}}</ref> in the historic Armour House at [[Lake Forest Academy]] in [[Lake Forest, Illinois]]. The couple have two children: daughter Locklyn Kyla Vaughn (born 2010) and son Vernon Lindsay Vaughn (born 2013).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20451757,00.html|title=Vince Vaughn Welcomes a Daughter|date=December 20, 2010|work=People|accessdate=April 29, 2013|first=Elizabeth|last=Leonard}}</ref><ref>Leonard, Elizabeth (August 9, 2013). [http://celebritybabies.people.com/2013/08/09/vince-vaughn-welcomes-son-vernon-lindsay/ "Vince Vaughn Welcomes Son Vernon Lindsay"]. ''People''; retrieved August 9, 2013.</ref>
Vaughn supported [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential candidate [[Ron Paul]] in both the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008]] and [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012]] elections,<ref>Costa, Robert (September 16, 2011) [http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/277507/vince-vaughn-ron-paul-you-re-so-money-robert-costa Vince Vaughn to Ron Paul: You’re So Money!], ''[[National Review]]''</ref> and [[Rand Paul]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Vince Vaughn Crashes Young Americans for Liberty Convention|url = http://blog.panampost.com/alice-salles/2015/04/27/vince-vaughn-crashes-young-americans-for-liberty-convention/|website = The Canal|access-date = 2016-02-08|language = en-US|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160219175125/http://blog.panampost.com/alice-salles/2015/04/27/vince-vaughn-crashes-young-americans-for-liberty-convention/|archive-date = February 19, 2016|dead-url = yes|df = mdy-all}}</ref> He has also appeared at a number of [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] events.<ref>{{cite web|title=Why Vince Vaughn supports Ron Paul|url=http://dailycaller.com/2011/09/19/why-vince-vaughn-supports-ron-paul/|work=The Daily Caller|accessdate=September 19, 2011}}</ref>
In 2016, Vaughn began training [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]] at the Gracie Academy in [[Torrance, California|Torrance]], [[Los Angeles]] <ref>{{cite web | url = https://jiujitsutimes.com/vince-vaughn-earns-his-white-belt-in-gracie-jiu-jitsu/ | title = Vince Vaughn Earns His White Belt in Gracie Jiu-Jitsu | publisher = Jiu-Jitsu Times | accessdate = 20 February 2018}}</ref> and received his blue belt in February 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bjjee.com/bjj-news/actor-vince-vaughn-promoted-blue-belt-bjj-2-years-training/ | title = Actor Vince Vaughn Promoted to Blue Belt in BJJ After 2 years of Training | publisher = Bjj Eastern Europe | accessdate = 20 February 2018}}</ref>
On June 10, 2018 Vaughn was arrested on suspicion of drunken driving and resisting arrest in [[Manhattan Beach, California]] after failing a sobriety test at a police checkpoint.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Associated Press |author-link=Associated Press |title=Actor Vince Vaughn Arrested on Suspicion of Drunken Driving, Resisting Arrest |url=http://time.com/5307590/vince-vaughn-arrested-drunken-driving/ |date=10 June 2018 |access-date=10 June 2018 |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.]]}}</ref>

Comedy]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Teen Choice Awards|Choice Movie - Chemistry]] (<small>shared with [[Jennifer Aniston]]</small>) |{{WON}} |- | rowspan="2" |2007 | rowspan="2" |[[People's Choice Awards|People's Choice Award]] |[[People's Choice Awards|Favorite Leading Man]] |{{WON}} |- |[[People's Choice Awards|Favorite On-Screen Match-Up]] (<small>shared with Jennifer Aniston</small>) |{{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="2" |2008 | rowspan="2" |''[[Into the Wild (film)|Into the Wild]]'' |[[Gold Derby Awards|Gold Derby Award]] |[[Gold Derby Awards|Ensemble Cast]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award]] |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture]] |{{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="3" |2010 | rowspan="2" |''[[Couples Retreat]]'' |[[People's Choice Awards|People's Choice Award]] |[[People's Choice Awards|Favorite Comedy Star]] |{{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="2" |[[Teen Choice Awards|Teen Choice Award]] |[[Teen Choice Award for Choice Hissy Fit|Choice Movie - Hissy Fit]] |{{Nominated}} |- |{{n/a}} |[[Teen Choice Awards|Choice Activist]] |{{WON}} |- |2013 |''[[The Internship|The Intership]]'' |CinemaCon Award |Comedy Duo of the Year (<small>shared with Owen Wilson</small>) |{{WON}} |- |2017 |''[[Hacksaw Ridge]]'' |[[Australian Film Critics Association|Australian Film Critics Association Award]] |[[Australian Film Critics Association|Best Supporting Actor]] |{{Nominated}} |- |2018 |''[[Brawl in Cell Block 99]]'' |[[Saturn Award]] |[[Saturn Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] |{{Nominated}} |}
